title: Synthetic Recap
body:
NEW YORK — In a performance for the ages, Allan Houston authored a Madison Square Garden masterpiece, pouring in a career-high 37 points to will the New York Knicks to a thrilling 109-107 victory over the Boston Celtics.

From the opening tip, this was Houston’s showcase. The silky-smooth guard was a study in offensive efficiency, slicing through the Celtics’ defense with a dazzling array of pull-up jumpers and relentless drives. His 37 points were not just a number; they were the steady, beating heart of the Knicks' offense, a constant the Celtics simply could not contain.

While Patrick Ewing provided his customary brawn with 21 points and 13 rebounds, and Larry Johnson chipped in 16 points, the night belonged unequivocally to Houston. Every time Boston threatened to seize momentum, Houston had an answer. His scoring barrage carved the path, but it was a true team effort that sealed the win, with all five Knicks starters finishing in double figures.

The Celtics, led by Rick Fox’s 22 points and Antoine Walker’s 20, fought ferociously until the final buzzer. But on this night, they were mere witnesses to an individual eruption. Houston’s historic outing was the definitive chapter in a classic Eastern Conference battle, a scoring spree that echoed through the Garden’s hallowed rafters and secured a hard-fought win for the home team.
